thread.title: Wetherspoon boss tells of 'heartache' at having to sell iconic city centre pub
thread.title_full: Wetherspoon boss tells of 'heartache' at having to sell iconic city centre pub

author: Michael Muncaster
title: Wetherspoon boss tells of 'heartache' at having to sell iconic city centre pub
text:
Wetherspoon boss tells of 'heartache' at having to sell iconic city centre pub 11:30, 17 Jun 2016 On a visit to Newcastle pub tycoon Tim Martin gave his thoughts on the sale of the Union Rooms and the EU referendum Shares The video will start in 8 s Cancel Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
An iconic city centre pub has yet to find a buyer- a month after it went on the market. 
The boss of JD Wetherspoon has revealed that the company has yet to receive an appropriate offer for the Union Rooms on Westgate Road in Newcastle . 
The pub giant announced in May that the venue - bought for £5.6m only six months ago - would be sold as part of a company restructure. 
Mr Martin said: “We have got five pubs in Newcastle and we are opening up pubs in the suburbs of Newcastle, investing millions of pounds. 
“We put one pub too many in the centre. We think it is better to put our investment into ones that are a little further away. 
“So we will still have a Wetherspoon to go to in Newcastle but it does cause us heartache to lose the Union Rooms.” 
JD Wetherspoon chairman Tim Martin has been visiting 100 of the company's pubs to discuss arguments for leaving the EU 
Mr Martin made the comments in the Five Swans in Newcastle on Thursday as part of an EU referendum debate. 
An outspoken Brexit supporter Mr Martin has been visiting 100 of the chain’s pubs to chat with punters about whether Britain should stay or go. 
He said: “The EU is becoming more and more undemocratic. 
“The rules are made by an European commissioner who does not get elected and we can’t sack them. 
“We know from looking around the world that democracy always produces more prosperously, more jobs and more freedom as well. 
“If you look at Greece, Portugal and Spain, they are in big trouble and the EU is going the wrong way.” 
With less than a week to go until the polls open, the leave campaign has gained ground with an increasing numbers of poll results pointing to Brexit. 
The bookies have consistently given the remain campaign a bigger lead in the betting, but the odds to leave are now shortening. 
Mr Martin added: “I think in Newcastle there has been a lot of debate in our pubs and I know people are talking about it a lot. 
“I believe we have got a chance of winning. I am optimistic.”
